utterances: But the challenge here is that they do have plutonium, they do have this program, they do have the resources, to some extent to continue it forward.
And it's a game of chicken and a test of wills.
And, Dennis Ross, let me ask you.
As you mentioned, there is a broader audience for this, primarily in Tehran at the moment, but in other places as well.

The head of the IAEA, Mohamed El Baradei, said he was afraid that something like 30 nations could be on the cusp of becoming nuclear powers, not just the nine we have a the moment, declared and undeclared.
As you look ahead at this, the proliferation regime seems to be eroding - the anti-proliferation seems to be unraveling.
As nations come on, people are going to be anxious in Japan, in South Korea, in Taiwan, elsewhere in the Middle East should Iran develop nuclear weapons.
Is the genie out of the bottle?

Well, I'm not sure the genie is out of the bottle, but I think one of the critical things is to make sure that now you implement this resolution in a way that makes it very difficult for North Korea to proceed.
And if you really want success, you really have to get them to turn around.

If you could succeed in turning the Korean Peninsula into a de-nuclearized Korean Peninsula, then that I think would have a tremendously positive effect on strengthening the nuclear non-proliferation regime.
But if we end up with this being a situation where they don't back off, and if the Iranians draw the wrong conclusion - if the Iranians say, you know what?
There really wasn't any serious price that they paid until they tested, so all we have to do is let's go up to that point.
We just won't test.
But we'll keep going this way, and if they don't pay a price, we'll proceed in this fashion.
Now if that happens, then you may well the overall regime erode.
And as you've said quite rightly - you know, this is a regime that basically, many people at the time it was adopted back in 1968, thought wouldn't survive.
And yet we're talking about nine countries that have it now.
We're not talking about 30.
So when Dr. El Baradei talks about 30 who could be on the cusp, that should be a kind of wake-up call to say all right, look.
We have to be looking for ways to strengthen the regime, not see it weaken.

How we proceed with North Korea, what we do vis-Ã -vis Iran, what we do to try to strengthen what's known as the additional protocol, what we do to try to ensure maybe there's an international bank for the supply of enriched uranium fuel - all these things could be factors in terms of trying to make this a stronger regime, not to see it weaken.
Dennis Ross, thanks very much for being with us.
Ambassador Ross joined us here in Studio 3A.
He was special Middle East coordinator under President Clinton, currently a counselor at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.

Richard Haass joined us from the studios at the Council on Foreign Relations of New York, where he's now president of the council and former director of policy planning at the State Department under Colin Powell.
Thanks very much, Richard Haass.
And Michael Green was kind enough also to be with us in Studio 3A.
He's now an associate professor of international relations at Georgetown University, senior advisor at the Council for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, D.C.
We thank you for your time, as well.
Thank you.
When we come back, it's the TALK OF THE NATION Opinion Page.
Native American powwows are cultural gatherings, and they are competitions.
Prize money is at stake for dancers.
As part of our summer series, The World's A Stage, we go to Oneida Indian Reservation near Green Bay, Wis., to listen in.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
My name is Ashley Riley.
I'm a Ojibwe.
I dance the old-style fancy shawl.
They call it the butterfly dance, too, because it's really graceful and beautiful.
And it's developed more into a contemporary style as well, a lot more light steps and higher jumps and kicks.
I started dancing, probably, about when I was 5 years old.
My parents, they got us little fancy shawl outfits.
And me and my sisters - they kind of pushed us out into the powwows and was like, go dance.
(Beating drums, chanting).
My name is Craig Merick.
I live in Berkeley, Calif.
I'm originally from Lame Deer, Mont.
- travel all over the country - Native country - from the West Coast all the way to the East Coast.
So Native people, they travel the Indian circuit kind of like the way cowboys do with the rodeo.
(Beating drums, chanting).
There were Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and the Church of England - poor thing - and the government of Singapore and a number of retirement funds.
In a crowded tent encampment just behind where Martelly's supporters are gathering, Micheline Jean is washing clothes in a large metal bowl.
She says she won't be going to any of the presidential rallies.
(Through Translator) I'm not interested in any of them because since all those presidents are coming I never receive anything from them, any help at all.
I have to fight to survive, to do everything for my life, for my kids, so I'm not interested to go anywhere.
Jean says before the earthquake, her four children were in school but now none of them are.
Asked whether she thinks the next president could help her move out of her tarp-covered tent back into a real house, she says, that's not up to the president, it's up to God.
Jason Beaubien, NPR News, Port-au-Prince.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Renee Montagne.
Today in Your Health, keeping aging brains active.
Research shows that volunteering keeps older people socially engaged, and that is good for their health.
NPR's Joseph Shapiro reports on one school in Ohio that's put an innovative twist on volunteering.
Start from the beginning.
That's a good place to start.
Here's the scene you can find in lots of schools all over the country.
An older woman - she's a volunteer in the school - helps a seven-year-old boy read.
His walkie-talkie, the...
Antenna.
...antenna was dang...
Dangling.
But at this school in Cleveland, many of the volunteers aren't just elderly, they've been diagnosed with Alzheimer's, like the woman reading with the boy on the small couch in the school hallway.
But Walter just...
Ignored him.
...ignored him.
That's a pretty hard word.
Barbara Kelsey is 84.
Her red hair is covered with a silk scarf folded like a bandana.
She's sitting next to a young woman who picks her up at her assisted living facility and drives her to this school.
When there's a break in the reading, I ask Kelsey about her volunteer work.
You're a mentor here?
No. No. I'm...
Unidentified Woman #1: Yes.
Yeah.
Her name's Barbara Kelsey.
I am.
Barbara Kelsey.
So tell me what you do when you come to the school.
I don't do anything, really much, except I sit and listen to them.
And I, you know, tell them if they, you know, they don't know exactly how to do something, I help them figure it out.
Sometimes she remembers, but sometimes she doesn't.
I think you met Ms. Kelsey?
Cathy Whitehouse is the principal and cofounder of this small inner-city charter school.
It's called the Intergenerational School.
And part of its philosophy is to bring in lots of volunteers of all ages.
Cathy Whitehouse says last year Barbara Kelsey volunteered more than anyone.
She was the volunteer who was given the Volunteer of the Year award for the most hours at the school last year and turned to her caregiver at the luncheon and said why am I getting this.
And the young woman said to her, because you come here and read with the children.
And she said, I do?
Whitehouse says it doesn't matter, because Barbara Kelsey is good at what she does.
When you see her sitting with a child and reading, she's able to interact with that child in the moment.
She's able to read.
I firmly believe that she enjoys the time that she spends here.
And if she doesn't remember it five minutes later, it doesn't matter.
It's just been great to have her.
A person with dementia may no longer be able to read and comprehend an adult book, but Whitehouse realized they can still read a kid's book.
Cathy Whitehouse started this school eight years ago with her husband Peter.
He's a geriatric neurologist.
